We found that the degree of overlap between species was greater between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption than between species that were dissimilar in these respects. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, which is highly dependent on APOE isoform. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE E4 may accelerate the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses in the brain, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are well known, the effects of acute marijuana use on the brain are less clear. Here, we show that the brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA), is reduced in marijuana abusers, who have higher levels of negative emotionality and addiction. These findings suggest that the reduced reactivity to methylphenidate in marijuana abusers might contribute to their negative emotionality and addictive behaviors.

Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We find that the kingdoms of life concentrate at different locations on the planet, with plants (≈450 Gt C) being primarily terrestrial, whereas animals (≈2 Gt C) are mainly marine, and bacteria (≈70 Gt C) and archaea (≈7 Gt C) are predominantly located in deep subsurface environments. We also show that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. They are a key input for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. We report on a discovery of a continuous model of self-organized criticality (SOC) in tropical geometry. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe the connection between our model and pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. However, it is unclear how to control its electronic and optical properties. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and the bandgap can be reduced to zero, by applying strain. This opens up a new route to control the electronic and optical properties of diamond. We also show that diamond can be demetallized, and the bandgap can be restored, by applying tensile strain. This can be used to control the phase transition from diamond to graphite. Our work provides a new route to control the properties of diamond, and opens up a wide range of applications.

The study of the structure and function of peptides is of great importance for the development of new drugs. Here, we report the structure and antifungal activity of a unique peptide, which is a member of the highly diverse and abundant group of nodule-specific cysteine-rich peptides. The antifungal activity of the peptide is attributed to its ability to bind to fungal cell walls and to induce reactive oxygen species. The study also demonstrates the potential of this peptide as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes, and it is likely that the life history of sperm is critical to reproductive success. We show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the life history of sperm, and that these contributions are critical to the viability of sperm. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the life history of sperm and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–female reproductive tract interactions. This work provides a foundation for future studies of the molecular basis of sperm–female reproductive tract interactions and the evolution of these interactions.

The protein von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a critical component of the blood clotting system. In some people, mutations in VWF cause a bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that the A1 domain of VWF, which binds to platelets, can be switched to a second state by force, which is a critical physiological stimulus. This mechanism provides a mechanism for the pathophysiology of VWD. The results are important for understanding the role of VWF in the clotting system and for the development of therapies for VWD.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the subject of intense study for the last decade. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been much harder to study, and has been the subject of only a handful of studies. This study is a major step forward in the study of the human virome, and is the first to include over 45,000 unique human-associated viruses in a comprehensive database. The database is freely available to the community, and is a major resource for the study of the human virome.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the Earth system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the ACI process and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate the ACI process. The HSRL is able to measure the aerosol and cloud properties simultaneously. We demonstrate the capability of the HSRL to investigate the ACI process. The results show that the aerosol loading has no discernible effect on the liquid water path but increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a subject of debate for decades. The current estimate of 15 °C is based on isotopic evidence, but this interpretation has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding the isotopic record, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the record, and depositional environments. We here present evidence that the temperature of Earth’s surface decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. (Show more)

Ion channels are the main ion-conductive gates in the cell membrane. They are also the main targets of drugs. The opening and closing of ion channels are controlled by two gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow inactivation/recovery. We found that the BK channel’s inactivation is state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. We propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of inactivation. This study provides a new perspective on the mechanism of K+ channel inactivation. It also provides a new strategy for the development of drugs for K+ channel disorders. (Show more)

Malaria is a disease that has plagued humanity for thousands of years. The parasite, Plasmodium, uses a variety of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell (RBC), the target of the disease. Here, we show that the malaria parasite uses the erythrocyte surface receptor glycophorin A to alter the physical properties of the RBC membrane, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This is the first time that we have been able to show that the parasite alters the physical properties of the host cell, and it is a major change in our understanding of the invasion process.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. However, it is unclear how to control its electronic and optical properties. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and the bandgap can be reduced to zero, by applying strain. This opens up a new route to control the electronic and optical properties of diamond. We also show that diamond can be demetallized, and the bandgap can be restored, by applying tensile strain. This provides a route to control the phase transition from diamond to graphite. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. This work is expected to be of interest to researchers in materials science, physics, and engineering.

In this study, we found that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the impact of dry air on influenza disease outcome, which may be useful in the development of strategies to mitigate the impact of influenza in the context of climate change. (Show more)

The brain is thought to build syntactic structures in a left-corner fashion, starting with the simplest units and gradually building up to the most complex. We show that the brain does this operation in multiple areas of the brain, including the superior temporal sulcus and the inferior frontal gyrus. This suggests that the brain uses a merge operation to build syntactic structures, and that the merge operation is not limited to the left hemisphere.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major regulator of development, and its regulation is important for the proper functioning of the body. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin, which are similar at the protein level, are regulated at the transcriptional and proteostatic level, and that this regulation is important for tissue-specific regulation of the pathway. This is an example of a subtle difference that can have a large impact on the function of the pathway.

The brain circuit that promotes overeating is not well understood. Here we describe a circuit that may be involved in the development of obesity. This circuit is located in the brain’s reward system, and it is activated by electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus. We show that this circuit is necessary for the development of overeating, and we identify the brain regions that are necessary for this circuit. This work provides a foundation for future studies of the brain mechanisms that promote overeating and contribute to obesity.

The ability of plants to fix nitrogen from the atmosphere is a key process in the global nitrogen cycle and is essential for the growth of all plants. However, the natural nitrogen fixation process is inefficient, and the use of nitrogen-fixing bacteria as biofertilizers is a major driver of the global economy. Here, we demonstrate a method for the control of nitrogen fixation in a plant symbiosis, which could be used to improve the efficiency of nitrogen fixation and to develop a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work is a step toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis.

We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that combined remote-sensed deforestation alerts with training and incentives for community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss in the communities that participated. However, the estimated effects are imprecise because of the large number of false alarms generated by the remote-sensed deforestation detection system. Our results suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

We show that the web of a spider is an acoustic antenna that can detect the presence of an approaching predator or prey. The spider can then localize the source of the sound and, in some cases, even identify the type of animal. This is a unique example of an animal sensing the presence of an object in the environment without using its own body as a sensor.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause suffering and death, and the search for a vaccine continues. We report the design, construction, and evaluation of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD subunit vaccine candidate that is well-suited for large-scale production and elicits a strong immune response. This vaccine candidate is based on a variant of the RBD that is more easily produced and processed by the host cell, and it is more immunogenic than the RBD used in the currently approved vaccines.

We report on the identification of a ligand for the ALK/LTK family of tyrosine kinases, which is involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. This study provides a molecular basis for the involvement of ALK/LTK receptors in the development of the skin, hair, and eyes.

The emergence of plague, the most devastating disease in human history, is a mystery that has been the subject of intense research for centuries. We present the first ancient Yersinia pestis genomes from the Late Neolithic and Early Bronze Age, which provide a unique window into the early evolution of this pathogen. Our results reveal a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct lineage of plague that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. These data provide a new perspective on the early history of plague and its relationship to its vector, the flea. Our findings have important implications for our understanding of the origins of plague and its relationship to its vector. (Show more)

This work examined the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in the 2016 and 2020 presidential elections. We found that men’s and women’s endorsement of HM predicted support for Donald Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. They also have implications for understanding the role of masculinity in the current political climate.

The management of agricultural lands has been shown to be a major driver of the global carbon cycle. In the United States, the conversion of grasslands to cropland has led to the release of carbon to the atmosphere. We show that the management of agricultural lands can also be a driver of carbon sequestration. We demonstrate that the management of grasslands can be a tool for sequestering carbon in the soil. This study highlights the importance of grasslands in the global carbon cycle and the need for agricultural lands to be managed in a way that is beneficial to the environment.

The threat of zoonotic viral disease outbreaks is growing, and we lack a systematic approach to prioritize research and public health interventions. We developed a risk assessment framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, to identify and prioritize the highest-risk viruses that should be the focus of future research and public health interventions. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking of 887 viruses revealed that the top 12 were known zoonotic viruses, and the top 100 were 100% novel. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination services. The color of nectar is often an important cue for pollinators, but the chemical basis for this adaptation is poorly understood. We show that the red color of nectar in Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of two other vertebrate-visited plants, Jaltomata herrerae and Nesocodon, and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. Our findings suggest that the red color of nectar is a common and widespread adaptation that is likely to be favored by natural selection. This work provides a molecular basis for the evolution of a visually important trait in plants and may have implications for the study of vertebrate pollination.

We present a genome-wide analysis of a group of individuals from southern Germany who lived in the late 5th/early 6th century AD. Our results indicate that the genetic ancestry of men from this period is similar to that of modern northern and central Europeans, but that the genetic ancestries of women are very heterogeneous, including signals of genetic ancestry from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that some of the women had skull deformations, which may have been associated with the deformation of their crania. Our results suggest that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. Finally, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These findings have implications for our understanding of the processes that shaped the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings are important for the development of MERS-CoV vaccines and therapeutics. They also provide insights into the origin of MERS-CoV and the design of strategies to prevent future zoonotic outbreaks. We describe the use of a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to investigate a large cohort of febrile patients in Cambodia. We found that vector-borne pathogens were the most common clinical category, but that underappreciated zoonotic pathogens, such as Plasmodium knowlesi, leptospirosis, and coinfecting HIV, were also detected. This study demonstrates the feasibility of pathogen-agnostic mNGS investigation of febrile persons in resource-scarce settings and the potential for mNGS to be used as a tool for coordinated and ongoing pathogen surveillance. This can help to identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This study also highlights the importance of a global cloud-based platform for pathogen surveillance. Such a platform can be used to rapidly deploy and share resources, such as bioinformatics pipelines, to support pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings. This can help to mitigate the spread of pathogens and reduce the burden of disease.

The human genome is replicated in a process that is highly similar to the process used by the bacterium S. cerevisiae. However, there are some important differences, including the stability of the polymerase–clamp complex. In this study, we use a combination of biochemical and biophysical methods to determine the stability of the human pol δ–PCNA complex. We find that the human pol δ–PCNA complex is not as stable as the S. cerevisiae pol δ–PCNA complex. This difference has important implications for the human cell as it limits the processivity of the polymerase and promotes the rapid dissociation of the polymerase from the clamp on DNA lesions. These results provide a foundation for understanding the replication of the human genome. They also provide a framework for understanding the role of the clamp in other processes, such as transcription.

The origin of life is one of the most important and challenging problems in science. In this paper, we describe the first demonstration of the replication of genetic information in the absence of proteins.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our work also provides a method for measuring the physical changes in neighborhoods over time, which can be used to study the spatial distribution of urban change over time. This method can also be used to study the spatial distribution of physical improvements in other cities around the world.

The clinical characteristics of severe and critical COVID-19 patients are analyzed, and the therapeutic effect of tocilizumab is evaluated. The results show that tocilizumab is an effective treatment for severe and critical COVID-19 patients, which can reduce mortality and improve the clinical outcome immediately.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but it is also a toxic metal that can cause damage to cells. In this study, we show that the xan BGC, which encodes isocyanide products that bind copper, is present in several filamentous fungi, and that these fungi have the ability to secrete these products and use them to mediate interactions with competing microbes. These findings suggest that the xan BGC is a member of a family of fungal natural products that have the potential to influence the homeostasis of copper, and that these fungi may use this mechanism to influence interactions with competing microbes. This study provides insight into the role of fungal natural products in the regulation of metal homeostasis and the maintenance of microbial interactions. (Show more)

The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary deposit on Mars is a significant discovery. The tridymite is cogenetic with other crystalline minerals, and the deposit is a possible source of silica for the formation of the “red” deposits in Gale crater. The deposit is also a possible source of silica for the formation of the “yellow” deposits in the Jezero crater region.

Frost events are a major cause of crop and forest losses, and the frequency of these events is expected to increase in a warming world. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is changing, and that the resistance strategies of trees are also changing in response. Our results have implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the role of these cells in the pathogenesis of the disease is unclear. We found that the development of colitis required the transition of a subset of Th17 cells to Th1-like cells and that this process required the expression of both Stat4 and T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors. Moreover, Th17 cells could provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. This plasticity may be a key to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating disease that causes progressive degeneration of motor neurons and paralysis. There is a need for accurate disease modeling, identifying disease mechanisms, and developing therapeutics. We report a method to rapidly convert adult human fibroblasts from living ALS patients to induced neuronal progenitor cells and subsequent differentiation into astrocytes. This enables high-throughput drug screening to alleviate astrocyte-derived toxicity. Our findings may lead to the development of new therapies for ALS. This method may also be applicable to other neurodegenerative diseases. This method may lead to the development of new therapies for ALS. It may also be applicable to other neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

The gut microbiota of ticks is a complex community of bacteria, fungi, and viruses that is essential for the survival of the tick and the pathogen it harbors. We now show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the composition of the gut microbiota and facilitates the colonization of the pathogen in the tick. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of how a pathogen exploits an arthropod antibacterial protein to more effectively colonize its vector. This knowledge may be useful in the development of strategies to control the spread of vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The study of the origin and early evolution of the avian tail is therefore critical for understanding the origin of modern avian form. Here, we describe a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, and provide new insights into the origin of the avian tail.

We show that the water vapor in the stratosphere is increasing with tropospheric temperature, and that this increase is a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. This is the first time that this has been shown in a comprehensive model, and it is a significant step forward in understanding the role of water vapor in the climate system.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are able to change their color. In this study, we show that the occurrence of blue-green colors in vertebrates has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and that the mechanism is the same—the presence of a class of proteins that bind biliverdin. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of chlorosis, a phenomenon that is widespread in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. We also provide a new tool for the study of vertebrate color evolution.

Hypoxia is a common feature of solid tumors, and is associated with the maintenance of the stemness of cancer cells. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces expression of a demethylase of mRNA m6A, AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which in turn increases the expression of pluripotency factors and the tumorigenic potential of breast cancer cells. These findings suggest that ALKBH5 may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The Bible is one of the most important books in the world. It is also one of the most fragile. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century, and the source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy. Here, we report a simple and objective method for identifying the animal origin of parchment. The method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. We present a new age model for the extinction based on U-Pb zircon dates from five volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Decamillenial to millennial level resolution of the mass extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion. This will establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms.

The intestinal epithelium is the primary barrier between the host and the external environment. It is essential to maintain the homeostasis of the intestinal epithelium to prevent the invasion of pathogens and the release of inflammatory factors. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also found that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses. Our study provides a potential therapeutic strategy for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease. (Show more)

We have determined the structure of the spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 in complex with the receptor ACE2. We find that the spike glycoprotein of the currently circulating virus has a number of mutations that are associated with increased infectivity. We show that one of these mutations, D614G, leads to a more open conformation of the spike glycoprotein, which may facilitate binding to the receptor. This work provides insight into the mechanisms of increased infectivity of the currently circulating virus. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has resulted in a reduction in life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y. These findings highlight the need for urgent action to address the structural inequalities that have led to the disproportionate burden of COVID-19 and its consequences.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry, and the chemical properties of compounds are the basis of the chemistry of materials. The chemical properties of materials are the basis of the chemistry of matter, and so on. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms change with pressure, and that these changes can be used to predict and explain the chemistry of materials.

We show that human ignitions and fire suppression have been the dominant driver of global fire activity over the last century, and that this trend is likely to continue. However, our results suggest that the effects of fire on climate are likely to be positive, rather than negative, in the future. This is because of the large carbon storage capacity of terrestrial ecosystems, which is enhanced by reduced fire activity. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the carbon cycle, and the need to understand the effects of fire on climate in the context of climate change.

We show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, by the host to its symbiotic bacteria is a critical factor in the maintenance of the mutualism between the squid Euprymna scolopes and its bioluminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri. This glycan is delivered to the squid only at night, when the symbiotic organ is at its most active, and is catabolized by the symbionts to enhance their ability to produce light. This glycan-mediated control of the symbiotic organ’s activity may be a general mechanism for the regulation of the activities of epithelial-associated microbial communities in animals. This work provides a new perspective on the role of glycans in the immune maturation of the host and the nutrition of the symbiont. (Show more)

We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data. We use a sparse representation of an embedding space to identify a set of latent topics that can be interpreted as latent discourse atoms. We can infer the topic that generated a sequence of words. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. This approach can be applied to many domains, including social media, news, and medical records. We believe that this method will be of interest to researchers in many fields, including machine learning, natural language processing, criminology, and public health.

The Black Death, the deadliest epidemic in human history, is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. We show that the introduction of the plague bacterium into Europe was not a one-time event, but rather repeated over the course of four centuries. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe.

We provide evidence that a densovirus is the cause of the asteroid mass mortality event on the Pacific Coast of North America. This is the first report of a densovirus as a cause of a mass mortality event in asteroids. The virus is likely to have been present in the ecosystem for decades, and its detection in museum specimens suggests that it may have been present for much longer.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a disease with a poor prognosis, and there is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies. We show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the IL1RAP (IL1R3) receptor, which is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. We also show that an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling can suppress the proliferation of primary human AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This approach could be extended to other cancers in which IL1RAP is expressed on cancer stem cells. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human population. The settlement history of Madagascar is still debated, and we provide a comprehensive view of the genomic diversity of the Malagasy population. We find that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution of Europeans and Middle Easterners. The admixture happened recently, and the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island suggests that the settlement of Madagascar happened independently from Africa and Asia. Finally, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the genomic diversity of the Malagasy population, which is a unique population in terms of its biodiversity and its human population. Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate gene expression. In some cases, the small RNA encodes a protein that has a role in the regulation of the gene expression. In this study, we describe a small RNA that encodes a protein that has a role in the regulation of carbon metabolism. The protein is membrane associated and has a role in the regulation of the activity of an enzyme involved in the metabolism of glycerol.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our approach can be used to identify CDR changes that can alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics against SARS-CoV-2 variants. (Show more)

Crop condition is a key indicator of agricultural production, and is used by farmers, policy makers, and the general public. However, it is difficult to obtain in real time, and is only available for a small number of crops and countries. We show that the US Department of Agriculture Crop Progress and Condition survey, which is conducted by a large number of crop experts, can be used to monitor crop status in real time, and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our results demonstrate the potential of this approach for monitoring crop status in other countries and crops, and for providing early warnings of crop production anomalies.

Language processing is a complex task that involves the ability to integrate information over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is adaptive, meaning that it is sensitive to the history of the system. We show that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds, and that it is sensitive to context and serial order. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language. It also has implications for the study of memory in general.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is a key uncertainty in our understanding of the future evolution of the carbon cycle. In this study, we provide a synthesis of the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration measurements, and we find that the response of soil respiration to warming is highly variable across biomes. Our results suggest that the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration decreases with increasing temperature, and that this decrease is greatest in colder biomes. These results highlight the importance of considering the spatial variability of soil respiration in future studies, and they provide a unique perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration across a broad range of biomes.

The transition from autotrophy to parasitism is one of the most important evolutionary events in the history of life. It is associated with the loss of photosynthesis and the acquisition of a parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition to parasitism is associated with a relaxation of selection on the plastid genome, which is accompanied by a stepwise reduction in the functional complexity of the genome. Our results suggest that the transition to parasitism is associated with a stepwise reduction in the functional complexity of the plastid genome.

The impact of anthropogenic climate change on the probability of extreme droughts in southwestern South Africa is evaluated through a large ensemble of climate model simulations. The results show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 Cape Town drought by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. The findings are important for the design of drought risk management strategies in SSA. The results also highlight the need for urgent mitigation efforts to reduce the risk of future droughts. (Show more)

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has been a major advance in the field of materials science. However, the conditions under which they are formed are not understood. Here, we report the discovery of a new quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this new quasicrystal, which is the oldest known anthropogenic quasicrystal, provides a unique window into the conditions under which quasicrystals form and may help to shed light on the formation of naturally occurring quasicrystals.

The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring in (bacterio)chlorophylls is one of the most important reactions in photosynthesis. The enzymes that catalyze this reaction are not homologous, and the chemistry of the reaction is very different. The discovery of the third class of the enzyme in oxygenic phototrophs, and the identification of the protein that is required for it, is a major advance in our understanding of the evolution of this important reaction.

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in many neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). In this study, we found that neuroinflammation was phase specific, and the role of neuroinflammation was dependent on the cell type of the glial cells. We propose that glial ASK1 as a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. Our findings may also provide a better understanding of the role of neuroinflammation in other neurodegenerative diseases.

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. We find that the probability of drought years has increased in the past two decades, and that the probability of drought years is strongly linked to warm conditions. We also find that anthropogenic forcings have increased the probability of drought years. These findings have important implications for water management, ecosystem management, and climate adaptation in California and elsewhere.

Autism is a complex disorder with a large number of risk genes and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a molecular mechanism for autism and may help in the development of treatments. (Show more)

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of Ca2+ signaling in the immune system, and is also involved in the regulation of gene expression, cell growth and differentiation, and Ca2+ homeostasis. In this study, we identify mutations in the CRAC channel that result in a spectrum of disease phenotypes, and provide insights into the molecular function of the CRAC channel. Our findings suggest that modulation of the CRAC channel may be a promising therapeutic approach for the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related conditions.

We have developed a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease that recapitulates many of the features of the human disease. We have used this model to study the spreading of protein aggregates in the brain and the mechanisms that underlie this process. We find that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and spread throughout the brain, causing non–cell-autonomous pathology. We also find that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These findings provide a unique platform for studying the mechanisms of spreading and the propagation of disease in neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks through spillover to other animals and humans. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are very limited. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of MTX in the immune system and the potential for MTX as a therapeutic target. These findings are of great importance for the prevention and control of viral diseases in bats and humans. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and thus requires one-carbon units for purine and thymidine synthesis. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the one-carbon unit-generating enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase, and show that it blocks the growth of colon cancer xenografts. We also show that the one-carbon unit donor is a critical determinant of the sensitivity of cancer cell lines to the inhibitor, and that this sensitivity is rooted in defective glycine import. Thus, we have identified a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells that can be targeted to block cell growth. This work has implications for the treatment of cancer, and for the design of new drugs.

We show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of patients with ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the coaggregating proteins have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a new perspective on the pathogenesis of ALS, and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The study of the origin of the flowering plants is hampered by the lack of fossils. In this paper, we describe a new genus and species of early flowering plant, Montsechia vidalii, and show that it is the sister group of Ceratophyllum, a group that is considered to be the most primitive group of flowering plants.

The evolution of viruses is a key component in understanding the origin of life, the emergence of pathogens, and the evolution of the human species. Here we present the first ancient viral sequences, which show that the human pathogen B19V has been associated with humans for a long time. We also show that the recombination event that formed the most common B19V genotype 2 occurred at a time when the human population was at its highest. These findings are important for understanding the evolution of viruses and the emergence of pathogens. They also have implications for the origin of life.

We provide a new estimate of the rate of sea level rise over the last 25 y, which is the longest period for which we have a consistent time series of satellite altimeter data. This estimate is important for understanding the rate of sea level rise over the last few decades, which is the period of time that is most often cited in the media and in public policy debates.

Pain is a major public health problem, and the number of Americans reporting pain is increasing. However, the increase in pain is not uniform across the population. Pain is higher in midlife than in old age, but pain is also higher in the less educated than in the more educated. The erosion of working-class life in the United States is reflected in the pain experience of today’s elderly.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. In this work, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed, chemically characterized picture of the reaction pathway of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate. This picture is key to understanding the reaction mechanism and to the design of inhibitors that can be used to control the activity of this enzyme and others.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe disease with a high case fatality rate. There is a need for the development of effective antiviral treatments. We show that remdesivir, a drug that was developed for the treatment of Ebola, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This study supports the development of remdesivir for the treatment of MERS and other coronaviruses. It may also be considered for the treatment of the novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV.

We show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, by the host to its symbiotic bacteria is a critical factor in the maintenance of the mutualism between the squid Euprymna scolopes and its bioluminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri. This glycan is delivered to the squid only at night, when the symbiotic organ is at its most active, and is catabolized by the symbionts to enhance their ability to produce light. This glycan-driven regulation of the symbiotic organ may be a general mechanism for the control of the activities of epithelial-associated microbial communities. This work provides a new perspective on the role of glycans in the immune system and in symbiosis. (Show more)

The present study provides important mechanistic insights into the molecular mechanisms of transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. The results from the present study are expected to provide a better understanding of the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis in vivo. The results are also expected to provide a better understanding of the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis in vivo.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe disease in humans. To understand the mechanisms of MERS-CoV infection, we engineered viruses with mutations that blocked sequential proteolysis of the spike glycoprotein. These mutations compromised infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into other cell types. These findings suggest that the first cleavages of the spike glycoprotein are significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence, and may be significant factors in the pathogenesis of other coronaviruses.

This study provides evidence that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can increase sales of vegetarian meals by 40%. This is a large effect, and it is achieved with a simple change to the catering system. The results suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering outlets could be a powerful way to improve population health and protect the environment. This approach could be applied in a wide range of settings, including schools, hospitals, and workplaces.

We have developed a method to measure the surfaceome of a cell, the interface between the cell and its extracellular environment. We find that the surfaceome is remodeled in a coordinated fashion by oncogenes, and that this remodeling is dependent on the MAPK pathway. We also find that the glycoproteome is similarly remodeled by oncogenes, and that this remodeling is dependent on the MAPK pathway. These studies provide a systems-level view of how oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a step toward understanding the role of the cell surface in cancer, and may lead to the development of new therapies.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our results suggest that vote-by-mail is a cost-effective way to increase turnout and safeguard the electoral process.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to the death of over 500,000 people in the United States as of this writing. The disease is caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, which has a number of unique features that have led to the development of vaccines and treatments. One of the most unique features of the virus is the ORF8 protein, which has been proposed to interfere with the host immune response. Here, we report the crystal structure of the ORF8 protein from SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19. We show that the structure of the protein is similar to that of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF7a protein, but with the addition of two unique interfaces that may be important for immune evasion. These results provide insight into the molecular basis of the unique features of the virus. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can induce cerebral edema, a potentially life-threatening condition. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this is mediated by the hypoxic release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. This study provides a mechanism for the development of cerebral edema in hypobaric hypoxia and may lead to the development of new therapies for this condition. (Show more)

We live in an era of big data. This is a boon for science, but it also brings new challenges. In this paper, we describe a new way of thinking about the problem of finding associations in big data. The key idea is that we must set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we find. This is a natural response to the fact that we have “cherry-picked” the data (i.e., searched for the strongest associations). We illustrate our approach in the context of forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The hope is that our approach will be useful to researchers in many fields.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step in the development of vascular networks, which is essential for the function of the vascular system. In this study, we found that ets variant 2 (ETV2) can directly induce the formation of functional vascular ECs (ETVECs) from human fibroblasts. This study provides a new strategy for the generation of ECs and the development of vascular networks. It also provides a new strategy for the treatment of vascular diseases. This study is expected to be a milestone in the field of vascular biology. (Show more)

We report the discovery of a third class of ligand for the RTKs anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk). We show that these ligands, which are encoded by two human genes, are essential for the development of the zebrafish iridophores, which are the zebrafish equivalent of human melanosomes. We also show that these ligands are essential for the development of the zebrafish iridophores, which are the zebrafish equivalent of human melanosomes. These findings establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides a foundation for understanding the function of these receptors in vivo and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer and melanoma. (Show more)

In this study, we found that STING is required for normal β-cell function, and its deficiency led to impaired GSIS. In addition, we found that Pax6 is the transcription factor that might be associated with defective GSIS in STING-βKO mice. These findings provide a new perspective for the role of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and the molecular basis for the pathogenesis of T2D.

Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of human influenza and cause severe pandemics. The genome of influenza A viruses is segmented into eight fragments, which is a potential advantage for the virus, but it also complicates the process of genome packaging. We identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments, which is required for optimal viral replication. This interaction is sequence specific and favors the copackaging of the interacting RNA segments. Our results indicate that the packaging of the influenza A virus genome is a complex process that involves a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of this network among influenza A viruses might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This study provides a better understanding of the molecular details of the influenza A virus replication process. It also provides a basis for the development of antiviral strategies. (Show more)

The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a complex process that involves a series of events, including the induction of proatherosclerotic phenotypes in vascular cells. In this study, we found that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) is a critical event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the progression of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising strategy for the prevention and treatment of atherosclerosis. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the functional role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the progression of atherosclerotic lesions. (Show more)

Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the Earth system for millennia. However, in recent decades, wildfire activity has increased substantially in the United States and around the world. In this study, we show that human activities have greatly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire, and that human-caused wildfires are now the dominant cause of wildfire in the United States. We argue that actions to reduce the risk of human-caused wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that the physical appearances of neighborhoods are related to the economic and demographic characteristics of their residents. Specifically, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements, and neighborhoods that are physically close to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods are more likely to experience improvements. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also highlight the importance of physical proximity in urban change.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and eco-friendly method of pest control. However, the molecular targets of these repellents in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we report the identification of a scorpion TRP channel as a receptor of natural repellents, which mediates avoidance behavior. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and may help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help the understanding of the evolution of plant–arthropod interaction. This work is expected to contribute to the conservation of biodiversity and the sustainable development of agriculture. (Show more)

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease and the optimal treatment are not fully understood. Here we present a mathematical model of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We provide estimates of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within an individual, and we assess the effect of an antiviral treatment on the time to clearance. Our results can help guide the development of treatment strategies and the design of clinical trials. (Show more)

Coral reefs are among the most diverse and valuable ecosystems on Earth. However, they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors. In this study, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This shift from net uptake to release of ammonium by the coral holobiont promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates, leading to the functional failure of the coral–algal symbiosis. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a barrier that protects the organism from the environment and regulates the absorption of nutrients. In this study, we show that the intestinal tumor microenvironment can alter the composition of the microbiome and the activity of the epithelium, leading to a loss of barrier function and dysregulated host–microbe interactions. We also identify a mechanism by which the microbiome can regulate the activity of the epithelium, and highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our work provides insights into the role of the microbiome in the regulation of the intestinal epithelium, and may have implications for the development of cancer therapies.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous, and some patients do not respond to treatment. We found that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, and that this enhanced the capacity of breast cancer cells to invade, form spheroids, engraft in Rag2−/−γc−/− mice, or survive treatment with paclitaxel. We also found that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. Thus, our results may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the onset of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is one of the most debated aspects of the last deglaciation. We show that the onset of accelerated deglaciation is linked to a volcanic eruption series, which, in turn, is linked to stratospheric ozone depletion.

Freshwater fisheries are an essential source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people, but their importance is often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which we use to assess the role of inland fisheries in food security, biodiversity conservation, and the sustainability of fisheries. We find that river fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, and that the spatial coincidence of productive fisheries and low food security highlights the critical role of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. At the same time, intensive fishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity. Our data can be used to improve the management of freshwater fisheries and protect the ecosystem services they provide.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable characters of the material are the key to achieve high energy density and safe aqueous batteries. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material, which is expected to be a milestone in the development of safe and high-energy aqueous batteries. This work also provides a new strategy for the development of safe and high-energy energy devices. The work is expected to be a milestone in the development of safe and high-energy energy devices.

In this study, we identify a form of regeneration in the nervous system that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This finding is important because it provides a new platform for the discovery of genes involved in the control of regeneration. It also provides a new model for the study of regeneration in the adult nervous system.

We describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a wild plant population. This provides a detailed view of the spatial organization of recombination in a flowering plant, and a reference for future studies of recombination in this important group of organisms.

The brain is organized in functional networks, which are thought to be involved in the control of cognitive functions. The present study provides a method for the identification of resting state networks in the human brain, based on the analysis of metabolic imaging. The method is able to identify the dominant resting state network in healthy subjects, and to identify a disease-related network in Parkinson’s disease. The method also provides a measure of the functional significance of the networks, which can be used to assess the impact of disease on the brain. The method can be used to monitor the progression of disease, and to assess the efficacy of treatment.

We report the discovery of a 5′ cap structure in yeast mRNAs that is modified with nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+). This finding is significant because it suggests that the 5′ cap structure is not the only modification that can be added to the 3′ end of mRNA. It also suggests that the 5′ cap structure may not be the only modification that can affect the stability and translation of mRNA.

We show that epigenetic DNA methylation differences at specific loci persist for several years in people with diabetes, and that these loci are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory, the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) on the progression of microvascular outcomes in the long-term follow-up Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study. These findings may also have implications for the understanding of the epigenetic basis of the metabolic effects of lifestyle interventions.

In this study, we show that the expression of a cancer antigen, FSIP1, is associated with poor prognosis in breast cancer. We also show that FSIP1 is associated with poor prognosis in triple-negative breast cancer, and its deficiency inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells. We further show that FSIP1 promotes autophagy, which in turn, inhibits the growth of TNBC cells in response to chemotherapy drugs. These findings may aid in the design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease that affects the brain and the gut. The present study shows that some alcohol-dependent subjects have altered gut barrier function, which is associated with depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in these subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of alcohol dependence and in the regulation of the gut barrier. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also provides a rationale for the use of probiotics in the treatment of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, many of which are nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthesis of these compounds is not known, and the role of the genes involved in their production in the overall flavor of tomato fruit is unclear. We have identified a gene essential for the production of all nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit, and we have shown that this gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase. This work provides a major advance in our understanding of the biosynthesis of tomato fruit flavor, and it will be a valuable resource for the breeding of improved varieties of this important crop.
