We show that the impacts of global warming on ecosystem functioning are dependent on the thermal tolerance of the species present in the community. We demonstrate that the presence of a diverse community is not sufficient to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress, and that the additional impacts of warming are dependent on the thermal tolerance of the species present. Our results highlight the importance of considering the thermal tolerance of species when assessing the impacts of global warming on ecosystem functioning.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, and its functional organization is poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in the MEC of freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which are thought to be essential for the formation of a spatial map, are organized separately from border, head-direction, and object-vector cells. These findings suggest that the organization of MEC cell types is more complex than previously thought and may be important for the formation of a spatial map. This work provides a detailed view of the organization of MEC cell types in a freely moving animal, which will be useful for understanding the function of MEC in navigation and other cognitive functions. This work also provides a platform for future studies of the organization of the MEC in other species. (Show more)

Flowering is a complex process, which is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the flowering signal, which is induced in leaves of the host plant, is required for flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how flowering can be regulated in a regressive manner, which is a common feature of parasites, and may be a general mechanism for flowering regulation in plants.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. We show that the dopamine-containing neurons of the substantia nigra, the primary source of dopamine in the brain, receive input from a novel specialized subsystem of the striatonigral fibers, which originate in the striosomes, a newly discovered region of the human striatum. This subsystem, which we term “striosome–dendron bouquets,” is likely to be critical to the function of the dopamine system in health and disease.

We asked people to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. We found that the speed at which people responded to each other was a robust predictor of how connected they felt. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that conversations with faster response times were perceived as more connected than the same conversations with slower response times. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.” This may be a fundamental mechanism for social connection.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for the generation of the heart rate. In this study, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of the SAN. We found that STIM1 is expressed in the specialized cardiomyocytes of the SAN, and its deletion in mice resulted in a reduction in the size of the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) in the specialized cardiomyocytes of the SAN, leading to a reduction in the number of SR Ca2+ stores, a reduction in the Ca2+ content of the SR, and a reduction in the automaticity of the SAN. These results suggest that STIM1 is a key regulator of SAN automaticity. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, and its beneficial effects on plant resistance against abiotic and biotic stresses have been well documented. However, the role of Si in mediating plant resistance against insect herbivores has not been examined. In this study, we show that the application of Si to rice plants increases the resistance of rice against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, by priming the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway and promoting the accumulation of Si in rice plants. These results suggest that the application of Si may be a promising strategy for the management of insect pests. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is an enzyme involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the metabolism of ether lipids in macrophages, and that it is involved in the regulation of the immune response.

Language processing involves the ability to integrate information over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on changes in the excitability of single neurons. We show that changes in the strength of synaptic connections can support memory, but that changes in the excitability of individual neurons is a simpler and more general mechanism. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and can support the binding of linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical step in the development of plant-based therapeutics. Here, we report the delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are important design parameters for the delivery of the nanostructures into the plant cells and the corresponding gene silencing efficiency. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be of interest to the plant biology community and the biomolecule delivery community in general. The work also has the potential to be extended to the delivery of other biomolecules such as proteins and peptides.

We show that the majority of the nutrients that fuel algal blooms in the nearshore areas of large lakes come from small tributaries, which are often overlooked in nutrient management efforts. Our findings have important implications for the management of coastal ecosystems, as well as for the design of nutrient reduction strategies for large lakes.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in the presence of a strong environmental forcing. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the dynamics of a driven quantum particle in a potential well, and it is a consequence of the interplay between the environmental forcing and the chemical kinetics of the system.

We show that the effects of an antibody against a glutamate receptor can lead to changes in the brain’s electrical activity, which can be modeled and validated in a mouse model. This model can then be used to identify the key synaptic parameters that best explain EEG paroxysms in pediatric patients with NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. Finally, we show that these same parameters can be used to predict the susceptibility of the brain to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in the presence of NMDAR-Ab. This work offers mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Ab, and may help to explain the diversity of EEG abnormalities observed in this disease. This work also provides a framework for understanding the effects of other types of antibodies on the brain’s electrical activity. The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid warming event, which is unprecedented in the last 2 million years. To understand the causes and consequences of such events, it is important to investigate the history of abrupt warming in the past. Here, we present a study of an abrupt warming event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was linked to a global warming and that the warming was driven by an increase in atmospheric CO2 and anoxia of the seafloor.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification reduces deforestation in oil palm plantations, but that most plantations are too small to have a significant impact on deforestation. We also show that certification has no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection. Our results suggest that certification is not yet having the desired impact on deforestation, and that the RSPO needs to improve its standards to achieve its goals.

The exocyst complex is a large protein complex that is essential for the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. In this study, we discovered a small molecule that inhibits the exocytosis process in both plant and human cells. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

In many vertebrates, the sex of an individual is determined by a single genetic locus. In species with polygenic sex determination, multiple alleles interact to produce the sex of an individual. Here we show that the interaction of multiple alleles can produce a modular system of sexual dimorphism, where the same genotype can produce different phenotypes. This modularity can be used to understand the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles.

The retina is a unique organ in that it is challenged by two distinct classes of reactive intermediates, one of which is generated by the oxidation of a retinal pigment epithelium-specific molecule, A2E, and the other of which is generated by the oxidation of a molecule that is a product of the degradation of the first. We show that the levels of iron in the retina, which is a site of accumulation of both molecules, impact the degradation of one of these molecules. This finding has implications for the treatment of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. (PsycINFO Database Record

Predators are the foundation of all food webs, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key driver of ecosystem functioning. In this study, we show that the evolution of predatory specialization is not a dead end, but rather a common evolutionary pathway that has led to the diversification of food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolutionary biology. The fossil record for the evolution of the human hand is fragmentary, however, and the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the hand, the third metacarpal styloid process, is unknown. We report the discovery of this feature in a 1.42-Myr-old hand from Kenya, which provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this feature and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This finding has implications for the evolution of the human hand and for the timing of the emergence of modern human behavior. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and thus requires one-carbon units for purine and thymidine synthesis. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the one-carbon unit-generating enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase, and show that it blocks the growth of colon cancer xenografts. We also show that the one-carbon unit donor is a critical determinant of the sensitivity of cancer cell lines to the inhibitor, and that this sensitivity is rooted in defective glycine import. Thus, we have identified a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells that can be targeted to block cell growth. This work provides a basis for the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics. This study provides evidence that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this impact can be mitigated by having access to natural landscapes such as forests. The results have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. The study also provides a framework for understanding the impact of deforestation on people’s diets, which can be used to inform future research and policy.

The mechanization of agriculture has greatly increased the capacity of farm machinery, allowing for the expansion of arable land and the production of more food. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We also provide a global map of subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction.
